title: Cyber Daily: Insurers Want to Avoid Covering War. Ukraine Hacks Put That to the Test.
text:
The decision could influence who foots the bill for any digital harm to U.S. companies in the event of Russian cyberattacks on Ukraine in the present conflict.

Continued below.

Turn knowledge into intelligence with Smart Data.

Ransomware and DDoS attacks have become events that every business must guard against. Paul Barrett, the CTO of NETSCOUT, explains how if you're not protecting everything, you're protecting nothing.

Watch Now

The geopolitical standoff highlights legal gray areas around modern warfare, which increasingly threatens to disrupt faraway corporate computer networks, security and insurance experts say. The prospect of Russia-linked cyberattacks that could spill out of Ukraine has also raised the stakes for businesses trying to understand what their insurance covers, as well as for insurers that fear a cascade of claims at once.

"The insurance industry, like many others, is one big pendulum between fear and greed," said Joshua Motta, chief executive of insurer Coalition Inc., which offers cyber-specific coverage.

Hackers recently disabled Ukrainian government computer networks and defaced official websites, leading Washington to warn of escalating breaches that could allow attackers to jump from initial targets in Ukraine to U.S. businesses.

While Ukrainian officials have blamed Russia for the hacks, the Kremlin has denied involvement, hinting at the difficulty of tying cyber activity to broader military campaigns.

German drug, tech companies targeted: Hackers linked to China are launching attacks on pharmaceutical, tech and other businesses in Germany, the country's Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution said Wednesday. Coca-Cola bottlers threaten work stoppage after cyber incident messes with paychecks. A union official representing workers at West Virginia facilities of Coca-Cola Consolidated Inc. said many people have received too little pay—or none at all—since hackers hit tech provider UKG Inc. in December. (WSAZ)

UKG's popular Kronos tools for logging employee hours were disrupted after a ransomware attack, which UKG disclosed on Dec. 11. Kronos customers span industries, including retail, government services, manufacturers, and healthcare systems.

About 25% of the Coca-Cola bottling workers represented by Teamsters Local #175 have been shorted pay, according to the union, which gave the bottling company until Monday to show how it will fix the paycheck problem.

The bottler will make good on worker pay, a spokeswoman said.
